Jamie McAllan.action: Shares a humorous and personal story about urinating in his helmet during a bombing run.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Sharing a personal and humorous anecdote is a way to build rapport and show openness, which suggests warmth and a desire to bond.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie confidently shares his experience flying B-25 bombers and recounts a vivid, challenging wartime anecdote about using his helmet as a urinal at high altitude.

Jamie McAllan.action: Drives Ronsel from town and offers to give him a ride again next Saturday afternoon.

Jamie McAllan.action: Sends Laura a bouquet of lavender with a congratulatory note upon learning she is pregnant.

Jamie McAllan.assessment: This invitation shows a desire for companionship and an effort to include Ronsel, indicating friendliness and a good-natured approach.

Jamie McAllan.action: Offers Ronsel a smoke and lights his own before tossing Ronsel the lighter.

Jamie McAllan.action: Compliments the saw mill by saying 'Well I love what you’ve done with the place.'

Jamie McAllan.action: Encourages Ronsel to come into the saw mill and shares a smoke with him, attempting to build rapport despite the dilapidated setting.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This shows social skill and emotional intelligence, indicating Jamie’s ability to connect with others even in difficult circumstances, a positive indicator of competence.

Jamie McAllan.action: Describes a combat situation over Austria where he maintained control of the B-25 bomber under heavy enemy fire, even as the co-pilot is killed.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This action strongly suggests Jamie’s skill, focus, and confidence under extreme pressure, demonstrating high competence in his role as a pilot.

Jamie McAllan.action: Swears to do something right if he survives the war, showing a desire to be good-natured and sincere despite uncertainty.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s vow to do something right if saved reflects an earnest and hopeful intention to be better and contribute positively, indicating underlying warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Salutes and acknowledges a fellow colored fighter pilot who saved him, returning the salute respectfully.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s respectful recognition of the fighter pilot, despite racial barriers of the time, shows tolerance, sincerity, and a friendly spirit.

Jamie McAllan.action: Expresses survivor guilt and humility by saying the men who died were better men than himself.

Jamie McAllan.action: Drinks with Ronsel and shares a meaningful look, forming a bond.

Jamie McAllan.action: Holds the B-25 bomber on course under heavy enemy fire after the co-pilot is killed.

Jamie McAllan.action: Makes a deal with God to do something right if he survives.

Jamie McAllan.action: Recognizes and acknowledges the arrival of P-38 fighter planes that save him.

Jamie McAllan.action: Expresses survivor guilt and self-deprecation, saying the men who died were 'lot better than me.'

Jamie McAllan.action: Jokes with the girls about keeping a lookout for Laura while building the shower.

Jamie McAllan.action: Shares a candid admission about his Silver Star medal being awarded for a foolish act and reveals his fear of water.

Jamie McAllan.action: Admits to receiving a silver star for being stupid and reveals a deep fear of water stemming from a childhood near-drowning experience.

Jamie McAllan.action: Shares a laugh and a drink with Ronsel, engaging in friendly conversation about their war experiences and personal memories.

Jamie McAllan.action: Asks Ronsel if he ever misses being overseas, showing interest in his feelings and experiences.

Jamie McAllan.action: Mentions missing some of the guys from the war and smiles when recalling different parts of the world and girls he met.

Jamie McAllan.action: Engages in a candid conversation about race and relationships with Ronsel, including asking if Ronsel has been with a white girl.

Jamie McAllan.action: Changed course during a mission to avoid flying over water despite his fear, then successfully hit the target and brought everyone back despite heavy enemy flak.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This action demonstrates Jamie's ability to adapt his plans based on personal limitations while still completing the mission successfully under dangerous conditions, indicating strong competence in skill and decision-making.

Jamie McAllan.action: Openly discusses his fear of water and past trauma with Ronsel, showing vulnerability.

Jamie McAllan.action: Engages in reflective conversation about missing aspects of military service and seeing the world.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie, passed out drunk outside the house, cries and seeks comfort in Laura's arms when she wakes him from a nightmare.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s vulnerability and willingness to seek comfort from Laura shows a sincere and trusting side, indicating warmth in his need for connection and emotional openness.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie abruptly leaves Laura’s embrace and drives away recklessly after waking from his nightmare.

Jamie McAllan.action: Passed out outside the house with an empty bottle of bourbon, clearly intoxicated.

Jamie McAllan.action: After waking, he quickly pulls away from Laura and insists he needs to leave, then drives off erratically.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jerks the truck toward the side of the road after dozing at the wheel.

Jamie McAllan.action: Slumps across the wheel crying and blubbering incoherently after getting the truck stuck in a ditch.

Jamie McAllan.action: Apologizes to Henry after the truck incident with a simple 'I'm sorry.'

Jamie McAllan.action: Laughs off spilling milk and makes a lighthearted comment 'no use crying over it.'

Jamie McAllan.action: Offers money to Henry to compensate for spilled milk, though in a sarcastic and half-hearted manner.

Jamie McAllan.action: Engages in a clumsy, half-hearted fist-fight with Henry after money is rejected.

Jamie McAllan.action: Disappears for days at a time doing whatever he pleases, ignoring Henry's expectations.

Jamie McAllan.action: Overshoots the road and slips into a ditch while driving, then flails and curses as he tries to free the truck, ultimately stripping the gears.

Jamie McAllan.action: Shuts off the engine and slumps across the wheel crying and blubbering incoherently, then falls asleep in the truck with headlights still on.

Jamie McAllan.action: Struggles to open the car door and stumbles out of the ditch the next morning, appearing hungover and haggard.

Jamie McAllan.action: Trips and falls, spilling milk everywhere while finishing milking the cow.

Jamie McAllan.action: Laughs off spilling milk and offers money sarcastically to Henry, then engages in a half-hearted, clumsy fist-fight.

Jamie McAllan.action: Responds to Laura's inquiry about supper and his departure with brief, somewhat closed-off answers.

Jamie McAllan.action: Admits to Laura that Henry kicked him out and that he probably had it coming.

Jamie McAllan.action: Packs his bags and decides to leave the farm after being asked to go.

Jamie McAllan.action: Plans to go out west to Los Angeles to stay with a war buddy.

Jamie McAllan.action: Frequently absent, drunk when present, and not contributing to the farm work as Henry complains.

Jamie McAllan.action: Warns Ronsel to put his head down when an oncoming car approaches.

Jamie McAllan.action: Gives Ronsel Jackson a ride in the truck and insists he can sit wherever he wants despite Pappy's racist objections.

Jamie McAllan.action: Arrives at the house drunk, rumpled, wet, but still greets his family with a smile and a friendly 'Well, hello, dear family.'
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Despite his apparent drinking problem, Jamie attempts to maintain a warm and friendly demeanor toward his family, showing some sincerity and good-naturedness.

Jamie McAllan.action: Drives a truck in bad weather, arriving at the house rumpled, wet, and smiling despite the conditions.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie demonstrates basic physical capability and resilience by managing to drive and arrive safely in poor weather, though his disheveled state and apparent intoxication suggest impaired judgment and lack of self-control.

Jamie McAllan.action: Offers Ronsel a ride and insists he can sit wherever he wants in the truck, standing up to Pappy's racist challenge.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie shows confidence and assertiveness in defending his choice to treat Ronsel as an equal, indicating social courage and a degree of moral competence, though this may provoke conflict within his family.

Jamie McAllan.action: Appears drunk and unsteady when arriving home, prompting Pappy's criticism.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie acknowledges Pappy's insult calmly by saying 'Yeah. I do.'
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie shows a degree of self-awareness and restraint in the face of verbal abuse, which may indicate a subdued but sincere nature rather than hostility.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie wobbles after Pappy's insults but does not retaliate aggressively.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie is poked awake by Pappy and then follows him and others to the saw mill despite his hesitation when seeing the white hoods.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s hesitation shows some internal conflict or fear, but his compliance suggests a lack of assertiveness or courage to oppose wrongdoing, which may reflect a lack of warmth in terms of protective or courageous behavior.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie stops when he sees the white hoods but is shoved along by Orris Stokes.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s pause indicates some moral hesitation or discomfort with the situation, which is a positive sign of conscience and potential warmth, though his failure to act on it is a negative indicator.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie wobbles and is described as 'too liquored up to be any good' by Pappy.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This suggests a lack of self-control and physical steadiness, indicating a momentary lapse in competence due to intoxication.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie is startled awake by Pappy and quickly bolts up, showing alertness to unexpected disturbance.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This shows a degree of situational awareness and responsiveness, a positive indicator of competence.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie hesitates and stops when he sees the Sheriff and Orris Stokes donning white hoods, showing caution.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This pause indicates some awareness of danger and a cautious approach, reflecting a moderate level of competence in assessing threats.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie complies with Pappy and Stokes, putting on boots and following them to the saw mill despite misgivings.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This compliance may reflect either a lack of assertiveness or a pragmatic choice to avoid immediate conflict; it shows limited agency and possibly reduced competence in resisting dangerous situations.

Jamie McAllan.action: Commands the men to turn Ronsel loose and confronts them despite the threat of violence.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie shows courage and a protective attitude toward Ronsel, indicating a strong sense of justice and empathy, which are positive indicators of warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Refuses to be intimidated by Stokes when he points a pistol at him, standing up firmly.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This demonstrates Jamie's sincerity and willingness to defend others, reflecting trustworthiness and friendliness toward Ronsel.

Jamie McAllan.action: Winces at the violence inflicted on Ronsel but does not intervene physically.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s visible discomfort shows empathy, though his inability to stop the violence may reflect limitations in his power or courage; still, the emotional response is a positive sign of warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Confronts a group of armed KKK men holding Ronsel hostage, demands they release him, and challenges Stokes who points a pistol at him.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie demonstrates considerable courage and assertiveness in a highly dangerous situation, showing confidence and willingness to stand up to threats, which are indicators of competence under pressure.

Jamie McAllan.action: Readies to lunge at Stokes after being threatened with a pistol.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This impulsive readiness to physically attack an armed man could be seen as brave but also reckless, suggesting a lack of strategic thinking or self-control in a critical moment.

Jamie McAllan.action: Insists on speaking up and intervening despite being told to shut up by Pappy and others.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Shows moral courage and a sense of responsibility, but also a possible underestimation of the danger or lack of tactical patience, which complicates the assessment of competence.

Jamie McAllan.action: Defends Ronsel against a racist mob threatening to lynch him, arguing that Ronsel fought for their country and demanding they release him.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie shows courage and a sense of justice by standing up for Ronsel despite the hostile and dangerous environment. This indicates a degree of warmth through loyalty and protection of others.

Jamie McAllan.action: Uses harsh language to describe the German women ('Fraulein cunts') and refers to the child as a 'half-breed bundle of joy' in a sarcastic manner.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s language here is coarse and dismissive, showing a lack of sensitivity and possibly bitterness. While his intent is to justify Ronsel’s situation, the choice of words detracts from warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Shoves Pappy out of the way when Pappy tries to intervene between him and Stokes.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s physical aggression toward Pappy, who is trying to de-escalate the situation, suggests impulsiveness and a lack of tact, which can undermine perceptions of warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Challenges the mob and tries to reason with them to spare Ronsel's life, invoking Ronsel's military service and threatening to go to the law.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This shows Jamie's courage, quick thinking, and willingness to stand up against violent injustice, indicating a degree of moral and situational competence.

Jamie McAllan.action: Uses blunt and provocative language ('Kraut whore', 'half-breed bundle of joy') to try to disrupt the mob's narrative.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: While the language is harsh and offensive, it is strategically used to challenge the mob's assumptions and momentarily sway their thinking, showing some tactical awareness.

Jamie McAllan.action: Shoves Pappy out of the way when Pappy tries to intervene between him and Stokes.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This physical assertiveness demonstrates Jamie's confidence and decisiveness in a dangerous situation, though it risks escalating violence.

Jamie McAllan.action: Fails to de-escalate the situation fully, resulting in Stokes moving toward him with a gun.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Despite his bravery, Jamie's approach is confrontational and may lack the subtlety or strategic patience needed to defuse a violent mob, indicating some limitations in competence under extreme pressure.

Jamie McAllan.action: Steps up and puts the gun barrel to his own forehead to de-escalate the situation.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This act shows courage and a willingness to sacrifice himself, possibly to protect others, indicating a deep sincerity and protective nature.

Jamie McAllan.action: Swipes the gun from Stokes and punches him to stop the threat.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie takes decisive action to protect himself and others from violence, demonstrating bravery and a protective instinct, which are aspects of warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Commands Dex to drop the shotgun and threatens to shoot if he does not comply.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: While forceful, Jamie’s actions aim to prevent further violence, showing a protective and responsible side, though the threat of violence tempers the warmth somewhat.

Jamie McAllan.action: Shoots a white hood in the leg to stop an attack.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie uses violence to defend himself and others, which is a necessary but harsh action; it shows his commitment to protection but also a willingness to harm, making this a mixed indicator of warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Fights fiercely when overwhelmed and beaten.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: His determination to resist harm reflects strength and resilience, but the aggressive fighting is more about survival than warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Steps up and puts the gun barrel to his own forehead to de-escalate the situation.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This shows a high level of courage and psychological insight, using a bold bluff to try to control a dangerous moment.

Jamie McAllan.action: Quickly swipes the gun from Stokes and punches him, then commands Dex to drop the shotgun while cocking the hammer.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Demonstrates quick reflexes, physical skill, and assertive command presence under extreme pressure, indicating strong competence.

Jamie McAllan.action: Maintains composure and attempts to control the crowd despite Pappy blocking his line of fire and verbal taunts.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Shows mental resilience and tactical awareness, though his inability to immediately neutralize the threat suggests some limitations.

Jamie McAllan.action: Shoots a white hood in the leg when charged, then fires another shot that misses before being tackled.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Exhibits effective use of a firearm in close quarters, but the missed shot and subsequent tackle indicate partial loss of control in the chaotic fight.

Jamie McAllan.action: Fights fiercely after being disarmed, using punches and kicks despite being outnumbered.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Shows determination, physical toughness, and fighting spirit, but ultimately is overwhelmed, highlighting limits in physical dominance or tactical support.

Jamie McAllan.action: Fails to prevent being tackled, disarmed, and beaten by multiple attackers.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Indicates a vulnerability in handling multiple assailants and a lack of backup or strategic advantage, which detracts from overall competence.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie refuses to decide Ronsel's punishment despite intense pressure and threats.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s refusal to participate in deciding a brutal punishment shows his moral integrity and empathy, indicating a sincere and good-natured character.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie ultimately gives in and mumbles a choice under extreme duress.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Although Jamie capitulates to save Ronsel’s life, this reluctant compliance under threat reflects the limits of his agency rather than a lack of warmth; it shows his protective instincts but also the tragic constraints he faces.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie locks eyes with Ronsel and struggles with the impossible choice.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This moment reveals Jamie’s deep internal conflict and empathy for Ronsel, highlighting his sincere concern and emotional warmth despite the horrific situation.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie averts his eyes when Stokes forces Ronsel’s mouth open.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s inability to watch the violence suggests sensitivity and emotional pain, reinforcing his compassionate nature.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie tries to push Pappy away despite being tied up and dazed.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This shows some physical resistance and presence of mind under extreme duress, indicating a basic level of capability and awareness.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie refuses to make a decision about Ronsel's punishment initially, saying 'No' multiple times.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This refusal demonstrates moral courage but also a paralysis in a critical moment, reflecting a lack of decisiveness and assertive leadership under pressure.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie ultimately capitulates and mumbles a choice to the Sheriff under threat.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This reluctant compliance under extreme coercion shows limited agency and inability to assert control, suggesting compromised competence in crisis decision-making.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie locks eyes with Ronsel, showing emotional connection and internal conflict.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: While this indicates empathy and emotional intelligence, it also reveals distraction and hesitation that undermine his ability to act decisively.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie averts his eyes when Stokes forces Ronsel's mouth open.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This avoidance suggests emotional overwhelm and inability to confront the brutal reality directly, indicating a lack of psychological resilience in this moment.

Jamie McAllan.action: Averts his eyes from the violent assault on Ronsel, unable to look at the brutality.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s inability to face the violence suggests discomfort and possibly empathy, indicating some sensitivity and internal conflict, which can be a subtle sign of warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Shakes Pappy violently and demands he wake up, then shoves a pillow over Pappy’s face, effectively suffocating him.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This act is cold, violent, and shows a lack of compassion or tolerance, indicating a severe absence of warmth in this moment.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie is thrown onto his bed, wet, beaten and unconscious, showing he was physically overpowered.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This indicates a moment of physical vulnerability and lack of control over the situation, reflecting a low level of competence in self-defense or situational control.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie stands by Pappy’s bedside during a storm, clenching a pillow in his hands and then violently shaking Pappy awake.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This shows emotional intensity and determination, but the method is impulsive and aggressive rather than skillful or confident, suggesting a lack of measured competence in handling conflict.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie shoves a pillow onto Pappy’s face, pressing harder until Pappy stops moving, then slowly removes the pillow.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This action demonstrates a decisive and forceful capacity to carry out a difficult and violent act, indicating a certain level of cold, grim competence in executing a plan, though morally questionable.

Jamie McAllan.action: Clutches the pillow he smothered Pappy with, showing visible distress and guilt.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s physical and emotional reaction indicates deep remorse and internal conflict, suggesting a capacity for empathy and sorrow despite his violent action.

Jamie McAllan.action: Attempts to stop the attackers from taking Ronsel.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Trying to intervene to protect Ronsel shows Jamie’s protective instincts and concern for others, reflecting a positive aspect of warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Says 'They made me choose' and shows signs of trauma and helplessness.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s admission of being forced into a terrible choice and his evident trauma reveal vulnerability and a lack of malice, which can be seen as a sign of sincerity and emotional openness.

Jamie McAllan.action: Smothers Pappy with a pillow, resulting in Pappy’s death.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Taking a life, even under duress, is a profoundly negative action that severely undermines Jamie’s warmth, indicating a capacity for violence and betrayal.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie smothers Pappy with a pillow, then sits clutching the pillow, beaten and desolate.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This action shows Jamie took a decisive and violent action under extreme pressure, indicating a capacity for difficult, grim decisions. However, his beaten and desolate state afterward suggests emotional and possibly physical overwhelm, which may limit his overall competence in handling the aftermath.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie tries to stop the attackers from taking Ronsel but admits there were too many of them.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This indicates Jamie’s willingness to intervene and protect others, showing courage and initiative. However, his inability to prevent the capture due to being outnumbered points to limitations in his effectiveness or physical capability in that moment.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie carries the burden of having to 'choose' under duress, implying he made a difficult decision forced upon him.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Making a forced choice under extreme pressure suggests mental resilience and a capacity to act decisively even in morally complex situations, which is a sign of competence. However, the lack of clarity about the nature of the choice and his emotional state tempers this assessment.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie does not explain or defend himself when Henry asks about his bruises, instead shaking his head and staring at his shoes.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s silence and avoidance here suggest a reserved or withdrawn demeanor, possibly indicating difficulty in expressing vulnerability or seeking support, which may limit warmth in this moment.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie hugs Henry after hearing about his father’s death, despite being racked with guilt and pain himself.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Offering physical comfort in a moment of shared grief shows Jamie’s capacity for empathy and connection, reflecting a sincere and supportive warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie helps Henry and Hap lower the coffin into the grave, cooperating in a difficult and somber task.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Participating in this communal act of respect and support demonstrates Jamie’s willingness to engage in shared hardship and responsibility, indicating a dependable and good-natured warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie approaches Henry and Laura after cleaning up despite being beat up.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This shows a level of resilience and composure, indicating Jamie can maintain presence and engage with others even when physically and emotionally strained.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie refuses to explain his bruises and instead looks down at his shoes.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This suggests a reluctance or inability to communicate openly about his situation, which may indicate emotional or social discomfort, reducing perceived competence in interpersonal communication.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie participates in lowering the coffin into the grave alongside Henry and Hap.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This action shows Jamie’s willingness to contribute physically and cooperate in difficult, somber tasks, reflecting practical capability and reliability.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie does not intervene or challenge Hap’s refusal to help with his son.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s non-action here could be seen as a lack of assertiveness or leadership in a tense situation, which may reflect a limitation in social or conflict management skills.

Jamie McAllan.action: Suggests allowing Hap to read from the Bible during the burial.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie shows openness and respect for Hap's faith and wishes, demonstrating tolerance and inclusiveness in a somber moment.

Jamie McAllan.action: Says 'Amen' along with others after Hap's reading.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: By joining in the ritual, Jamie participates sincerely and respectfully, indicating a friendly and sincere nature.

Jamie McAllan.action: Suggests allowing Hap to read from the Bible during the burial ceremony.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This shows Jamie's social awareness and willingness to support others' contributions, indicating good judgment and interpersonal skill.

Jamie McAllan.action: Says 'Amen' along with others after Hap's reading, despite the harsh tone.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie demonstrates emotional intelligence by participating respectfully in a difficult moment, showing maturity and composure.

Jamie McAllan.action: Interrupts Hap as he is leaving by saying 'Hap, wait.'
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This suggests Jamie is proactive and confident enough to engage others when necessary, indicating leadership potential and attentiveness.

Jamie McAllan.action: Gives a photo of Ronsel and Franz to Florence to pass on to Ronsel if she sees him.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This action shows Jamie’s care and concern for Ronsel, indicating a thoughtful and sincere nature.

Jamie McAllan.action: Watches his brother shoveling dirt and looks back with guilt, then turns away despite Laura’s pleading eyes.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s guilt suggests an awareness of his emotional distance or failure to act supportively, and his turning away indicates a withdrawal rather than engagement, reflecting a lack of warmth in this moment.

Jamie McAllan.action: Expresses hope that Ronsel is well and that his father’s death brought peace to the Jackson family.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Jamie’s internal hope for others’ well-being and peace shows a good-natured and sincere side, reflecting warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Remains emotionally numb and drinks alone in a Los Angeles apartment, hoping for a miracle for his friend Ronsel.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: While Jamie’s hope for his friend is warm, his emotional numbness and isolation suggest a withdrawal from warmth in his own life, indicating a conflicted or diminished warmth.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie pulls out the photo of Ronsel and Franz and gives it to Florence to pass on if she sees Ronsel.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This shows Jamie's thoughtful and deliberate approach to maintaining connections and his awareness of others' roles, indicating emotional intelligence and situational awareness.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie looks back at his brother shoveling dirt but then turns away and keeps walking despite Laura's pleading eyes.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This suggests a moment of emotional conflict and possible avoidance, indicating a lack of decisiveness or courage to confront difficult family matters directly.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie walks through the grand lobby of Union Station with a small pack, takes a couple of swigs from a flask, and reflects on his thoughts about Ronsel and his family.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: His calm, reflective demeanor and ability to carry on despite emotional pain suggest mental resilience and self-control, which are aspects of competence.

Jamie McAllan.action: Jamie smokes a cigarette and drinks bourbon in a 1940s LA apartment, appearing numb and hoping for a miracle for his friend Ronsel.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: This behavior indicates a degree of emotional withdrawal and escapism, which may undermine his ability to act effectively or confidently in his life.

Jamie McAllan.action: Florence agrees to help Henry by going to care for his sick children despite the risk and inconvenience to her own family.
Jamie McAllan.assessment: Although this action is performed by Florence, Jamie McAllan's presence in the scene and the fact that Henry comes to the McAllan household for help suggests Jamie's household is seen as trustworthy and warm. Jamie's indirect association with Florence's willingness to help indicates a warm environment fostered by Jamie.
